title: Compute and Interpret Quality of Functional Spaces
text: tutorial illustrates compute interpret quality functional spaces using mFD, special emphasis functional dendrograms functional spaces low dimension distort original trait-based distances. tutorial also explains square-rooting original distances computing PCoA may misleading.

title: Compute and Interpret Quality of Functional Spaces
text: DATA dataset used illustrate tutorial fruit dataset based 25 types fruits. fruit characterized 5 traits summarized following table:  NOTE dataset subset dataset used mFD: General Workflow tutorial keep non-fuzzy traits.  dataframe gathering species traits, looks follows:  Species x traits dataframe based fruits dataset  Thus, dataset contains 5 traits: 3 ordinal (Size, Climate, Seed), 1 categorical (Plant type), 1 continuous (sugar content):   traits summed following dataframe (details: mFD: General Workflow tutorial):
code: data("fruits_traits", package = "mFD")  # remove non-fuzzy traits: fruits_traits <- fruits_traits[1:5]  # plot the table: knitr::kable(head(fruits_traits),               caption = "Species x traits dataframe based on *fruits* dataset") ##       Size     Plant           Climate     Seed        Sugar        ##  0-1cm  :2   forb : 5   temperate  :15   none: 2   Min.   : 16.90   ##  1-3cm  :6   shrub: 3   subtropical: 4   pip :17   1st Qu.: 73.70   ##  3-5cm  :5   tree :14   tropical   : 6   pit : 6   Median : 92.40   ##  5-10cm :6   vine : 3                              Mean   : 90.66   ##  10-20cm:6                                         3rd Qu.:105.80   ##                                                    Max.   :162.50 fruits_traits_cat <- data.frame(names(fruits_traits), c("O","N","O","O","Q")) colnames(fruits_traits_cat) <- c("trait_name", "trait_type") fruits_traits_cat ##   trait_name trait_type ## 1       Size          O ## 2      Plant          N ## 3    Climate          O ## 4       Seed          O ## 5      Sugar          Q

title: Compute and Interpret Quality of Functional Spaces
text: First, trait-based distance species computed using mFD::funct.dist(). use Gower distance.  USAGE  Gower distances range < 0.01 0.790. instance, Gower distances blackberry 3 fruits :   observed differences values intuitively related trait values 4 species:   Indeed: blackberry shares 3 traits values currant 2 species close values 2 traits explains low distance (< 0.1) blackberry shares 2 traits cherry (size climate), differs slightly seed size (1 order) quite different terms plant type sugar content, hence Gower distance around 0.5 blackberry maximally different banana ordinal traits, difference categorical sugar content differ 2.5 factor, hence Gower distance high (> 0.8).

previous_headings: 3. Compute functional space, quality metrics and plot them
what: 3.1. Compute functional spaces and associated quality metrics
title: Compute and Interpret Quality of Functional Spaces
text: now compute varying number functional space 1 9 dimensions based PCoA well UPGMA dendrogram using mFD::quality.fspaces() function. also compute 4 quality metrics (= combinations deviation weighting distance scaling) (details: mFD General Workflow tutorial, step 4.1).  USAGE  best space (minimum deviation trait-based distance space-based distance) 4D according indices. using output mFD::quality.fspaces(), plot quality metrics space:    NB higher value metric, higher deviations trait-based space-based distance species, hence lower quality functional space .  can notice : inaccuracy dendrogram (shown right) much higher inaccuracy spaces made least 3 dimensions ranking spaces slightly affected quality metric, higher values indices based squared deviation scaling distance increases inaccuracy dendrogram  FD indices eventually computed coordinates space (hence raw distance), hereafter consider mean absolute-deviation metric.  raw absolute deviation distances dendrogram 2, 3, 4D spaces plotted thanks mFD::quality.fspaces.plot() function:  USAGE   2D 3D spaces bias distance (hence high deviation, see top row) species pairs closer spaces close trait values. 4D space species pairs accurately represented (absolute deviation < 0.1).
code: # use quality.fpscaes function to compute quality metrics: quality_fspaces_fruits <- mFD::quality.fspaces(   sp_dist             = dist_fruits,   fdendro             = "average",   maxdim_pcoa         = 9,   deviation_weighting = c("absolute", "squared"),   fdist_scaling       = c(TRUE, FALSE)) ## Registered S3 method overwritten by 'dendextend': ##   method     from  ##   rev.hclust vegan # display the table gathering quality metrics: quality_fspaces_fruits$"quality_fspaces" ##                     mad       rmsd mad_scaled rmsd_scaled ## pcoa_1d      0.14960800 0.19275417 0.14395689  0.18875975 ## pcoa_2d      0.07260544 0.10110390 0.07492961  0.10306073 ## pcoa_3d      0.04696520 0.06505328 0.04730734  0.06524948 ## pcoa_4d      0.04000008 0.05415334 0.03430576  0.04874494 ## pcoa_5d      0.04946642 0.06180911 0.03885764  0.05214018 ## pcoa_6d      0.05537470 0.06660442 0.04286165  0.05561341 ## pcoa_7d      0.05951430 0.06979397 0.04572100  0.05826640 ## pcoa_8d      0.06353017 0.07314032 0.04796894  0.06039689 ## pcoa_9d      0.06464350 0.07410817 0.04882052  0.06119030 ## tree_average 0.08204566 0.10937029 0.19229494  0.22468355 # retrieve the functional space associated with minimal quality metric:  apply(quality_fspaces_fruits$quality_fspaces, 2, which.min) ##         mad        rmsd  mad_scaled rmsd_scaled  ##           4           4           4           4 library("magrittr")  quality_fspaces_fruits$"quality_fspaces" %>%   tibble::as_tibble(rownames = "Funct.space") %>%   tidyr::pivot_longer(cols =! Funct.space, names_to = "quality_metric", values_to = "Quality") %>%   ggplot2::ggplot(ggplot2::aes(x = Funct.space, y = Quality,                                 color = quality_metric, shape = quality_metric)) +   ggplot2::geom_point() mFD::quality.fspaces.plot(   fspaces_quality = quality_fspaces_fruits,    quality_metric  = "mad",   fspaces_plot    = c("tree_average", "pcoa_2d", "pcoa_3d", "pcoa_4d", 'pcoa_5d'))

title: Compute and Interpret Quality of Functional Spaces
text: NB Many pairwise distance dendrogram deviate 0.3 trait-based distances (top-left panel figure), particularly highest distances dendrogram corresponding pairs species actually close trait values (Gower distance < 0.3). dichotomous nature dendrogram implies many species pairs distance, especially species pairs different sides tree root maximal distance.  instance, let’s consider 3 fruits: lemon, lime cherry:   2 Citrus fruits similar trait values differ cherry. Now let’s look pairwise distances: Gower distance trait values, Euclidean distance 4 dimensions PCoA space cophenetic distance UPGMA dendrogram.   expected given trait values, Gower distance lime lemon 2.75 (0.44/0.16 = 2.75) times lower distance cherry. Euclidean distances 4D space (pcoa_4d) similar Gower distance, slight overestimation. Meanwhile, UPGMA dendrogram, lime distant lemon cherry lemon even closer cherry lime. illustration usual bias dendrogram overestimates distance pairs species actually similar trait values.  Now let’s look distance pineapple fruits:    cophenetic distance dendrogram pineapple species banana 0.53 trait-based Gower distance 22 fruits varied two-fold magnitude 0.32 (water melon) 0.73 (currant). homogenization distance due ultrametricity dendrogram, .e. species distance species main branch (.e. descending root). Let’s plot UPGMA dendrogram:    notice pineapple ‘outer’ group tropical fruits lime ‘close’ cherry lemon.
code: # get fruits traits: fruits_traits[c("cherry", "lime", "lemon"), ] ##          Size Plant     Climate Seed Sugar ## cherry  1-3cm  tree   temperate  pit 128.2 ## lime    3-5cm  tree    tropical  pip  16.9 ## lemon  5-10cm  tree subtropical  pip  25.0 quality_fspaces_fruits$"details_fspaces"$"pairsp_fspaces_dist" %>%   dplyr::filter(sp.x %in% c("cherry", "lime", "lemon") &                  sp.y %in% c("cherry", "lime", "lemon")) %>%   dplyr::select(sp.x, sp.y, tr, pcoa_4d, tree_average) %>%   dplyr::mutate(dplyr::across(where(is.numeric), round, 2)) ##    sp.x   sp.y   tr pcoa_4d tree_average ## 1 lemon cherry 0.44    0.46         0.26 ## 2  lime cherry 0.50    0.54         0.34 ## 3  lime  lemon 0.16    0.22         0.34 quality_fspaces_fruits$"details_fspaces"$"pairsp_fspaces_dist" %>%   dplyr::filter(sp.x %in% c("pineapple") | sp.y %in% c("pineapple")) %>%   dplyr::mutate(fruit = stringr::str_replace_all(string = paste0(sp.x, "", sp.y),                                                  pattern = "pineapple", replacement = "")) %>%   dplyr::select(fruit, Gower_distance = tr, Cophenetic_distance = tree_average) %>%   ggplot2::ggplot(ggplot2::aes(x = Gower_distance, y = Cophenetic_distance, label = fruit)) +   ggplot2::geom_point(size = 1) +   ggplot2::geom_text(size = 2, nudge_y = 0.08, check_overlap = TRUE) +   ggplot2::geom_abline(slope = 1, intercept = 0) +   ggplot2::scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0, 1)) +   ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 1)) quality_fspaces_fruits$"details_fspaces"$"dendro" %>%   as.dendrogram() %>%   dendextend::plot_horiz.dendrogram(side = TRUE)

what: 3.3. Focus on the effect of square-rooting distance matrix before computing PcoA
title: Compute and Interpret Quality of Functional Spaces
text: known ‘issue’ associated Gower metric applied non-continuous traits distance matrix Euclidean. Let’s look:   FALSE fruit case: actually intuitive formula Gower metric categorical traits binary (see example )  Applying PCoA non-Euclidean distance eventually leads PC axes negative eigenvalues. axes meaningless removed default ape::pcoa() function used mFD::quality.fspaces() function.   , PCoA 25 fruits species described 5 traits produced 9 PC axes positive eigenvalues.  deal non-Euclidean ‘issue’, recommended square-root Gower distance matrix computing PCoA. However Gower distance definition 0 1, 0 < x < 1, sqrt(x) > x: transformation means square-root distances higher raw distances difference raw square-root distances varies non-linearly raw distances.  look raw square-rooted Gower distance blackberry 3 species:   Raw Gower distance blackberry banana almost twice higher distance blackberry cherry 10 times higher distance blackberry currant. Square-root distance blackberry banana differs 1.5 3-fold factor distance blackberry cherry currant, respectively high slope square-root function (close 0). apply mFD::quality.fspace() square-root Gower distance:   inaccuracy (measured mAD (mean absolute deviation) metric) decreases number axes 0.  forget input used square-root Gower distance. let’s compare deviation trait-based Gower distance Euclidean distance 24D PCoA space:    expected, ranking distances ‘perfectly’ kept square-root shape 1:1 line.  now compute actual mAD Gower Euclidean distances apparently perfect 24D space:   notice mAD = 0.212: inaccuracy much higher worst space dendrogram computed raw Gower distance matrix represent actual difference trait values  sum : non-continuous traits ofteh make Gower distances species non-Euclidean PCoA Gower distance lead PCoA axes negative eigenvalues remaining axes always represent accurately Gower distance (details see Maire et al. (2015) especially Figure 2). Square-root transformed Gower distance apparently increasing efficiency PCoA (negative eigenvalue) Euclidean distance space square-root biased representation trait-based distances key features account computing FD  NOTE: convinced Gower intuitive non-Euclidean consider following simple case 8 species described 3 categorical traits (2 modalities ), 8 unique combinations trait values 28 species pairs sharing 0, 1, 2 trait values:   thus 3 distances values, 0.33, 0.67 1, depending number traits values (0, 1 2)   applying squareroot transformation, (1/0.33) 3-fold difference Gower distance pairs species sharing trait value pairs species sharing 2 traits becomes (1/0.58) < 2. Thus, applying square-root transformation Gower distance decreases magnitude variation trait-based distance, increasing distances similar species

title: Compute and Interpret Quality of Functional Spaces
text: Maire et al. (2015) many dimensions needed accurately assess functional diversity? pragmatic approach assessing quality functional spaces. Global Ecology Biogeography, 24, 728-740.

title: Compute Functional Diversity Hill Indices
text: tutorial explains compute family indices presented Chao et al. (2019) using mFD.

what: Let’s load data and compute functional distance
title: Compute Functional Diversity Hill Indices
text: data set used illustrate tutorial fruits dataset based 25 types fruits (.e. species) distributed 10 fruits baskets (.e. assemblages). fruit characterized six traits values summarized following table:  load three objects used compute functional framework (explanations, see mFD General Workflow):  data frame summarizing traits values species called fruits_traits tutorial: Species x traits data frame based fruits dataset  matrix summarizing species assemblages called baskets_fruits_weights tutorial. Weights matrix can occurrence data, abundance, biomass, coverage, etc. studied example works biomass (.e. grams fruit basket) matrix looks follows: Species x assemblages matrix based fruits dataset  data frame summarizing traits types called fruits_traits_cat tutorial (details, see mFD General Workflow): Traits types based fruits & baskets dataset  , can compute functional distance using mFD::funct.dist() function follows: USAGE
code: data("fruits_traits", package = "mFD")  knitr::kable(head(fruits_traits),       caption = "Species x traits data frame based on the **fruits** dataset") data("baskets_fruits_weights", package = "mFD")  knitr::kable(as.data.frame(baskets_fruits_weights[1:6, 1:6]),               caption = "Species x assemblages matrix based on the **fruits** dataset") data("fruits_traits_cat", package = "mFD") knitr::kable(head(fruits_traits_cat),               caption = "Traits types based on **fruits & baskets** dataset") ## Error in get(paste0(generic, ".", class), envir = get_method_env()) :  ##   object 'type_sum.accel' not found ## [1] "Running w.type=equal on groups=c(Size)" ## [1] "Running w.type=equal on groups=c(Plant)" ## [1] "Running w.type=equal on groups=c(Climate)" ## [1] "Running w.type=equal on groups=c(Seed)" ## [1] "Running w.type=equal on groups=c(Sugar)" ## [1] "Running w.type=equal on groups=c(Use,Use,Use)"

what: Generalisation of Hill numbers for alpha functional diversity
title: Compute Functional Diversity Hill Indices
text: family indices presented Chao et al. (2019) allows computing FD based pairwise distance species weights assemblages. generalization Hill numbers framework based two parameters: q: importance species weight compared species distance. Values allowed mFD 0, 1, 2 (often used, see ). tau: threshold functional distinctiveness two species (.e. species distance threshold considered functionally equally distinct). Values allowed mFD “min(imum)”, “mean(imum)” “max(imum)”.  Indices expressed effective number functionally equally distinct species (virtual functional groups) thus directly compared taxonomic Hill numbers (including species richness).  NOTE details properties Hill numbers FD read Chao et al. (2019) especially Figures 1 & 2.  indices can computed function mFD::alpha.fd.hill().  start comparing ‘classical’ Rao’s quadratic entropy expressed Hill numbers following Ricotta & Szeidl (2009) special case q = 2 tau = "max".  USAGE  , can compute Hill numbers FD order 2 computed tau = "mean" q = 2 recommended Chao et al. (2019)  USAGE  can now compare two metrics:  can see FD computed tau = "max" less variable (ranging 1.50 1.86) FD computed tau = "min" (ranging 1.72 4.10) illustrating higher sensitivity functional differences species.  NB Note even q = 0, weights species still accounted FD. Hence, goal compute richness-like index (.e. accounting distance species present), function mFD::alpha.fd.hill() applied species occurrence data (coded 0/1, previously computed using sp.tr.summary) species weight). Species occurrence data can retrieve mFD::asb.sp.summary() function:  USAGE  can see baskets composition fruits species FD values (e.g basket_1, basket_2 basket_3)
code: baskets_FD2max <- mFD::alpha.fd.hill(   asb_sp_w = baskets_fruits_weights,    sp_dist  = fruits_gower,    tau      = "max",    q        = 2) baskets_FD2mean <- mFD::alpha.fd.hill(   asb_sp_w = baskets_fruits_weights,    sp_dist  = fruits_gower,    tau      = "mean",    q        = 2) round(cbind(FD2max  = baskets_FD2max$"asb_FD_Hill"[ , 1],              FD2mean = baskets_FD2mean$"asb_FD_Hill"[ , 1]), 2) ##           FD2max FD2mean ## basket_1    1.50    2.62 ## basket_2    1.83    3.97 ## basket_3    1.86    4.10 ## basket_4    1.27    1.72 ## basket_5    1.30    1.85 ## basket_6    1.74    3.73 ## basket_7    1.82    3.94 ## basket_8    1.40    2.16 ## basket_9    1.53    2.75 ## basket_10   1.53    3.01 # Retrieve species occurrences data: baskets_summary    <- mFD::asb.sp.summary(baskets_fruits_weights) baskets_fruits_occ <- baskets_summary$"asb_sp_occ"  head(baskets_fruits_occ) ##          apple apricot banana currant blackberry blueberry cherry grape ## basket_1     1       0      1       0          0         0      1     0 ## basket_2     1       0      1       0          0         0      1     0 ## basket_3     1       0      1       0          0         0      1     0 ## basket_4     1       0      0       0          0         0      0     0 ## basket_5     1       0      0       0          0         0      0     0 ## basket_6     1       0      1       0          0         0      0     0 ##          grapefruit kiwifruit lemon lime litchi mango melon orange ## basket_1          0         0     1    0      0     0     1      0 ## basket_2          0         0     1    0      0     0     1      0 ## basket_3          0         0     1    0      0     0     1      0 ## basket_4          0         1     1    0      0     0     0      1 ## basket_5          0         1     1    0      0     0     0      1 ## basket_6          0         0     0    1      1     1     0      1 ##          passion_fruit peach pear pineapple plum raspberry strawberry tangerine ## basket_1             1     0    1         0    0         0          1         0 ## basket_2             1     0    1         0    0         0          1         0 ## basket_3             1     0    1         0    0         0          1         0 ## basket_4             0     1    1         0    1         0          0         1 ## basket_5             0     1    1         0    1         0          0         1 ## basket_6             0     0    0         1    0         0          0         0 ##          water_melon ## basket_1           0 ## basket_2           0 ## basket_3           0 ## basket_4           0 ## basket_5           0 ## basket_6           1 # Compute alpha FD Hill with q = 0: baskets_FD0mean <- mFD::alpha.fd.hill(   asb_sp_w = baskets_fruits_occ,    sp_dist  = fruits_gower,    tau      = "mean",    q        = 0)  round(baskets_FD0mean$"asb_FD_Hill", 2) ##           FD_q0 ## basket_1   4.73 ## basket_2   4.73 ## basket_3   4.73 ## basket_4   1.93 ## basket_5   1.93 ## basket_6   4.57 ## basket_7   4.57 ## basket_8   3.67 ## basket_9   3.67 ## basket_10  3.52

what: Generalisation of Hill numbers for beta functional diversity
title: Compute Functional Diversity Hill Indices
text: Framework Chao et al. (2019) also allows computing beta-diversity, 2 framework similar Jaccard Sorensen ones taxonomic diversity. mFD:beta.fd.hill() function computes indices.  NB Note total weight assemblages affecting computation functional beta-diversity. Hence reflect ecological pattern (e.g. rather difference sampling effort), recommended apply mFD::beta.fd.hill() relative weight species assemblages.   Now can compute functional beta-diversity order q = 2 (tau = "mean" higher sensitivity) Jaccard-type index:  USAGE can see basket 1 similar (beta < 0.1) baskets 2,3,4,5,10 dissimilar basket 8 (beta > 0.5). Baskets 4 5 highly dissimilar (beta > 0.8) basket 8.
code: # retrieve total weight per basket: baskets_summary$"asb_tot_w" ##  basket_1  basket_2  basket_3  basket_4  basket_5  basket_6  basket_7  basket_8  ##      2000      2000      2000      2000      2000      2000      2000      2000  ##  basket_9 basket_10  ##      2000      2000 # Here baskets all contain 2000g of fruits, we illustrate how to compute... # relative weights using the output of asb.sp.summary:  baskets_fruits_relw <- baskets_fruits_weights / baskets_summary$"asb_tot_w" apply(baskets_fruits_relw, 1, sum) ##  basket_1  basket_2  basket_3  basket_4  basket_5  basket_6  basket_7  basket_8  ##         1         1         1         1         1         1         1         1  ##  basket_9 basket_10  ##         1         1 # Compute index: baskets_betaq2 <- mFD::beta.fd.hill(   asb_sp_w  = baskets_fruits_relw,    sp_dist   = fruits_gower,    q         = 2,   tau       = "mean",    beta_type = "Jaccard")  # Then use the mFD::dist.to.df function to ease visualizing result mFD::dist.to.df(list_dist = list("FDq2" = baskets_betaq2$"beta_fd_q"$"q2")) ## Registered S3 method overwritten by 'dendextend': ##   method     from  ##   rev.hclust vegan ##          x1        x2        FDq2 ## 1  basket_1  basket_2 0.058982325 ## 2  basket_1  basket_3 0.078716397 ## title: Continuous Traits Framework
text: tutorial explains workflow used compute functional space based continuous traits shows retrieve species coordinates species functional distances functional space.  DATA tutorial uses dataset one 80 CESTES database Jeliazkov & CESTES consortium (2019)) based [Villeger et al. 2012] (https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0040679). data frame contains 45 fish species Terminos Lagoon (Gulf Mexico) gathered 36 sites considered assemblages. species described 16 continuous morphological traits.  dataset gathers continuous traits, functional space can computed using one trait one dimension using Principal Component Analysis (PCA: convert correlations among samples 2D plot). NB Using PCoA continuous traits euclidean distance using PCA (clusters made minimizing linear distance (PCoA) obtained maximizing linear correlations (PCA)).

title: Continuous Traits Framework
text: species traits data frame rows corresponding species columns corresponding traits. different traits summed following table:   work mFD continuous traits, must load two objects:  sp_tr: species x traits data frame Species x Traits data frame based CESTES dataset  asb_sp_w: species x assemblages data frame summarizing biomass recorded volume 4500m3 per site per species: Species x Assemblages data frame based CESTES dataset first six species first seven sites
code: # load dataset: sp_tr <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_cestes_sp_tr.csv",                                package = "mFD"), dec = ",", sep = ":")  rownames(sp_tr) <- sp_tr$"Sp" sp_tr <- sp_tr[ , -1]  # display the table: knitr::kable(head(sp_tr),               caption = "Species x Traits data frame based on *CESTES* dataset") # load dataset: asb_sp_w <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_cestes_asb_sp_w.csv",                                   package = "mFD"), dec = ",", sep = ":")  rownames(asb_sp_w) <- paste0("site", sep = "_", asb_sp_w$Sites) asb_sp_w <- asb_sp_w[ , -1]  asb_sp_w$Urobatis_jamaicensis <- as.numeric(asb_sp_w$Urobatis_jamaicensis)  # remove sites 12, 23, 35 because FRic can not be computed on it... # ... (for a clean example): asb_sp_w <- asb_sp_w[-c(11, 22, 33), ]  # display the table: knitr::kable(asb_sp_w[1:7, 1:6],               caption = "Species x Assemblages data frame based on *CESTES* dataset for the first six species and first seven sites")

title: Continuous Traits Framework
text: Based species-trait data frame species-standardized traits data frame, mFD allows build functional space based PCA using trait dimension. (NB Using 1.0.3 version mFD package allow weighting continuous traits, done next version package. can use col.w argument PCA function FactomineR package.). function used compute functional space continuous traits called mFD::tr.cont.fspace() used follow:  USAGE  takes inputs: sp_tr data frame pca argument must set TRUE want compute PCA FALSE want use trait dimension construct multidimensional space nb_dim argument referring maximum number dimensions multidimensional functional spaces. Final number dimensions depends number positive eigenvalues obtained PCA pca = TRUE number traits used pca = FALSE. NB High value nb_dim can increase computation time. scaling argument allowing traits values standardized. can standardized several ways: standardization range value trait, center-transformation, scale transformation scale-center transformation can used. can also chose standardize traits values. NOTE Scaling ensures trait-based distances distances functional space maximum. Scaling distances implies quality functional space accounts congruence distances rather equality compute_corr argument refers string value compute Pearson correlation coefficients traits using “pearson” using “none”.  example, compute PCA based maximum number 7 dimensions get Pearson’s correlation coefficients:   PCA computed, output contains: quality metrics spaces 2 dimensions nb_dim dimensions: NB mean absolute deviation (mad) reflects actual magnitude errors affect distances, hence FD metrics ; mean squared deviation (msd) reflects potential risk associated species pairs strongly misplaced functional space (Maire et al. (2015)).   NB lower quality metric , better quality space . , thanks mAD mSD value, can see number dimensions increases, quality increases. However, decrease computation time, can chose work 6D space good quality functional space. Generally, must keep mind trade-number axes quality functional space. Increasing number functional axes increases computation time.  eigenvalues, percentage variance explained cumulative percentage variance explained axis nb_dim dimensions:   matrix species coordinates functional space:   dist object containing species euclidean distances functional space (5D space first five species):   dist object containing species distances based traits (first five species):   correlation matrix containing correlation traits associated pvalue:   can notice strong correlation traits. NB However, strong correlation found, one two correlated trait can remove analysis. PCA computed, outputs except mad msd computed one distance object returned.

code: # Load data: data("baskets_fruits_weights", package = "mFD") # Display the table: knitr::kable(as.data.frame(baskets_fruits_weights[1:6, 1:6]),        centering = TRUE,       caption = "Species x assemblages matrix based on the **fruits** dataset") # Load data: data("fruits_traits", package = "mFD") # Remove fuzzy traits in this tutorial: fruits_traits <- fruits_traits[ , -c(6:8)] # Display the table: knitr::kable(head(fruits_traits),              caption = "Species x traits data frame") # Load data: data("fruits_traits_cat", package = "mFD") # Remove fuzzy traits in this tutorial: fruits_traits_cat <- fruits_traits_cat[-c(6:8), ] # Thus remove the "fuzzy_name" column: fruits_traits_cat <- fruits_traits_cat[ , -3] # Display the table: knitr::kable(head(fruits_traits_cat),               caption = "Traits types based on **fruits & baskets** dataset")

code: sp_dist_fruits <- mFD::funct.dist(   sp_tr         = fruits_traits,   tr_cat        = fruits_traits_cat,   metric        = "gower",   scale_euclid  = "scale_center",   ordinal_var   = "classic",   weight_type   = "equal",   stop_if_NA    = TRUE) # Quality of functional spaces: fspaces_quality_fruits <- mFD::quality.fspaces(   sp_dist             = sp_dist_fruits,   maxdim_pcoa         = 10,   deviation_weighting = "absolute",   fdist_scaling       = FALSE,   fdendro             = "average")  # retrieve species (fruits) coordinates in the 4D space (see General tutorial): sp_faxes_coord_fruits <- fspaces_quality_fruits$"details_fspaces"$"sp_pc_coord" alpha_fd_indices_fruits <- mFD::alpha.fd.multidim(   sp_faxes_coord   = sp_faxes_coord_fruits[ , c("PC1", "PC2", "PC3", "PC4")],   asb_sp_w         = baskets_fruits_weights,   ind_vect         = c("fric"),   scaling          = TRUE,   check_input      = TRUE,   details_returned = TRUE)

code: # Compute the range of functional axes: range_sp_coord  <- range(sp_faxes_coord_fruits)  # Based on the range of species coordinates values, compute a nice range ... # ... for functional axes: range_faxes <- range_sp_coord +     c(-1, 1) * (range_sp_coord[2] - range_sp_coord[1]) * 0.05 range_faxes ## [1] -0.5214338  0.4850924 # get species coordinates along the two studied axes: sp_faxes_coord_xy <- sp_faxes_coord_fruits[, c("PC1", "PC2")]  # Plot background with grey backrgound: plot_k <- mFD::background.plot(range_faxes = range_faxes,                                 faxes_nm = c("PC1", "PC2"),                                color_bg = "grey95") plot_k

code: # Retrieve vertices coordinates along the two studied functional axes: vert <- mFD::vertices(sp_faxes_coord = sp_faxes_coord_xy,                         order_2D = FALSE,                        check_input = TRUE) plot_sp_vert <- mFD::pool.plot(ggplot_bg = plot_k,                              sp_coord2D = sp_faxes_coord_xy,                              vertices_nD = vert,                              plot_pool = TRUE,                              color_pool = "black",                              fill_pool = NA,                              alpha_ch =  0.8,                              color_ch = NA,                              fill_ch = "white",                              shape_pool = 3,                              size_pool = 0.8,                              shape_vert = 16,                              size_vert = 1,                              color_vert = "green",                              fill_vert = "green") plot_sp_vert plot_k <- mFD::pool.plot(ggplot_bg = plot_k,                              sp_coord2D = sp_faxes_coord_xy,                              vertices_nD = vert,                              plot_pool = FALSE,                              color_pool = NA,                              fill_pool = NA,                              alpha_ch =  0.8,                              color_ch = "white",                              fill_ch = "white",                              shape_pool = NA,                              size_pool = NA,                              shape_vert = NA,                              size_vert = NA,                              color_vert = NA,                              fill_vert = NA) plot_k

text: part, shamelessly use loop follow: USAGE Structure loop compute many FRic plots wanted (combination functional axes): plots PC1, PC2, PC3 PC4 Let’s now look plot_FRic list contains FRic plots three studied assemblages (basket_1, basket_6 basket_10). contains many element combination two axis four studied axis:
code: ####### Preliminary steps:  ## Compute the range of functional axes: range_sp_coord  <- range(sp_faxes_coord_fruits)  ## Based on the range of species coordinates values, compute a nice range ... ## ... for functional axes: range_faxes <- range_sp_coord +     c(-1, 1) * (range_sp_coord[2] - range_sp_coord[1]) * 0.05   ####### Create a list that will contains plots for each combination of axis: plot_FRic <- list()  ####### Compute all the combiantion we can get and the number of plots axes_plot <- utils::combn(c("PC1", "PC2", "PC3", "PC4"), 2) plot_nb   <- ncol(axes_plot)   ######## Loop on all pairs of axes: # for each combinaison of two axis: for (k in (1:plot_nb)) {      # get names of axes to plot:     xy_k <- axes_plot[1:2, k]               ####### Steps previously showed          # a - Background:     # get species coordinates along the two studied axes:     sp_faxes_coord_xy <- sp_faxes_coord_fruits[, xy_k]      # Plot background with grey backrgound:     plot_k <- mFD::background.plot(range_faxes = range_faxes,                                 faxes_nm = c(xy_k[1], xy_k[2]),                                color_bg = "grey95")               # b - Global convex-hull:     # Retrieve vertices coordinates along the two studied functional axes:     vert <- mFD::vertices(sp_faxes_coord = sp_faxes_coord_xy,                         order_2D = FALSE, shape_vert = NA,                              size_vert = NA,                              color_vert = NA,                              fill_vert = NA)               # c - Assemblages convex-hulls and species:          # Step 1: Species coordinates:     # basket_1:     ## filter species from basket_1:     sp_filter_basket1 <- mFD::sp.filter(asb_nm = c("basket_1"),                                 sp_faxes_coord = sp_faxes_coord_xy,                                       asb_sp_w = baskets_fruits_weights)     ## get species coordinates (basket_1):     sp_faxes_coord_basket1 <- sp_filter_basket1$`species coordinates`                 # basket_6:     ## filter species from basket_6:     sp_filter_basket6 <- mFD::sp.filter(asb_nm = c("basket_6"),                                 sp_faxes_coord = sp_faxes_coord_xy,                                       asb_sp_w = baskets_fruits_weights)     ## get species coordinates (basket_6):     sp_faxes_coord_basket6 <- sp_filter_basket6$`species coordinates`               # basket_10:     ## filter species from basket_10:     sp_filter_basket10 <- mFD::sp.filter(asb_nm = c("basket_10"),                                 sp_faxes_coord = sp_faxes_coord_xy,                                       asb_sp_w = baskets_fruits_weights)     ## get species coordinates (basket_10):     sp_faxes_coord_basket10 <- sp_filter_basket10$`species coordinates`               # Step 1 follow-up Vertices names:     # basket_1:     vert_nm_basket1 <- mFD::vertices(sp_faxes_coord = sp_faxes_coord_basket1, sp_faxes_coord_basket10,                                       order_2D = TRUE,                                        check_input = TRUE)               # Step 2: plot convex-hulls and species of studied assemblages:     plot_k <- mFD::fric.plot(ggplot_bg = plot_k,                     asb_sp_coord2D = list("basket_1" = sp_faxes_coord_basket1, what: What is the difference between nominal and ordinal traits?
title: FAQ
text: Nominal traits used describe features biologically categorized, growth form plants diet animals. Hence, nominal coding implies categories equally distinct . Ordinal traits coded using discrete values like nominal traits, categories meaningful ranking, either trait intrinsically continuous (e.g. body size categorized small, medium, large bins), ecologically relevant consider ordered categories. example, period activity animals coded “diurnal”, “nocturnal” “”, relevant consider generalist species “” functionally intermediate two specialists “diurnal” “nocturnal”. distinction important calculating functional distances using Gower metric (e.g., mFD::funct.dist() function). fact, using nominal traits species different trait values distance , using ordinal traits, species pairs neighboring categories (e.g., “small” “medium” size) lower distances species pairs distant categories (e.g., “small” “large”). Ordinal traits thus treated similarly continuous traits nominal ones. Trait coding vary across case studies depending categories considered. example, diet coded using categories describing main preys (e.g. leaves, seeds, fruits, invertebrates, vertebrates) nominal coding relevant, diet coded using broader categories actually reflecting trophic levels (e.g. plants, plants & animals, animals) considered ordinal trait. Note two categories, coding trait ordinal ordinal impact. mFD::funct.dist() function, uses gawdis() function (gawdis package)(https://rdrr.io/cran/gawdis/man/gawdis.html) handles ordinal traits various methods. Using mFD::funct.dist() function, able choose among three methods commonly used, can : classic treats ordinal variables continuous variables, metric refers Eq. 3 Podani (1999), podani refers Eqs. 2a-b Podani (1999). last two options convert ordinal variables ranks. mFD::funct_dist() default classic final distance two species doesn’t depend traits values species (case two options).

title: FAQ
text: computing Gower distance species, data includes quantitative, categorical, fuzzy traits. However, applying PCoA Gower distances can lead negative eigenvalues, mFD package support corrections like Lingoes Cailliez. ? ecologists, know collecting trait values studied species time consuming eventually want sure FD indices computed space faithfully represents traits values, hence Gower distance computed . Faithfulness measured deviation metrics mAD rmSD compare raw distances based traits values distances functional space. Based simulations, Maire et al (2015) demonstrated always faithful space (low mAD) without applying correction (note first PC axes kept build faithful spaces always positive eigenvalues). Even square root transformation distance PCoA prevents negative eigenvalues, actually alters actual distances species based trait values took lot care (effort/time) accurately measure/retrieve .Similarly, Cailliez correction also modifies distances adding constant values, affecting relative differences . Therefore, since goal ensure FD indices computed space faithfully represents raw trait values, recommend applying corrections.

title: How to Deal With Functional Entities
text: DATA dataset used illustrate tutorial fruits dataset based 25 types fruits (.e. species) distributed 10 fruit baskets (.e. assemblages). fruit characterized six trait values summarized following table:   NOTE reduced dataset used mFD General Workflow keep ordinal categorical traits. Categorical traits restrained 2 3 modalities per traits limit number unique combinations.  following data frame matrix needed: data frame summarizing traits values species called fruits_traits data frame tutorial:  Species x traits dataframe based fruits dataset  matrix summarizing assemblages called basket_fruits_weights tutorial:  Species x assemblages dataframe based fruits dataset  data frame summarizing traits categories called fruits_traits_cat tutorial: (details: mFD General Workflow)  Traits types based fruits & baskets dataset  Using mFD::asb.sp.summary() function, can sum assemblages data retrieve species occurrence data:
code: data("fruits_traits", package = "mFD")  fruits_traits <- fruits_traits[ , 1:4]      # only keep the first 4 traits to illustrate FEs  # Decrease the number of modalities per trait for convenience ... # ... (to have less unique combinations of trait values):  # Size grouped into only 3 categories: fruits_traits[ , "Size"] <- as.character(fruits_traits[ , "Size"])  fruits_traits[which(fruits_traits[ , "Size"] %in% c("0-1cm", "1-3cm", "3-5cm")), "Size"] <- "small" fruits_traits[which(fruits_traits[ , "Size"] == "5-10cm"), "Size"]  <- "medium" fruits_traits[which(fruits_traits[ , "Size"] == "10-20cm"), "Size"] <- "large"  fruits_traits[ , "Size"] <- factor(fruits_traits[, "Size"], levels = c("small", "medium", "large"), ordered = TRUE)  # Plant type grouped into only 2 categories: fruits_traits[ , "Plant"] <- as.character(fruits_traits[, "Plant"])  fruits_traits[which(fruits_traits[ , "Plant"] != "tree"), "Plant"] <- "Not_tree" fruits_traits[ , "Plant"] <- factor(fruits_traits[ , "Plant"], levels = c("Not_tree", "tree"), ordered = TRUE)  # Plant Origin grouped into only 2 categories: fruits_traits[ , "Climate"] <- as.character(fruits_traits[ , "Climate"])  fruits_traits[which(fruits_traits[ , "Climate"] != "temperate"), "Climate"] <- "tropical" fruits_traits[ , "Climate"] <- factor(fruits_traits[, "Climate"], levels = c("temperate", "tropical"), ordered = TRUE)  # Display the table: knitr::kable(head(fruits_traits), caption = "Species x traits dataframe based on *fruits* dataset") data("baskets_fruits_weights", package = "mFD")  knitr::kable(as.data.frame(baskets_fruits_weights[1:6, 1:6]),               caption = "Species x assemblages dataframe based on *fruits* dataset") data("fruits_traits_cat", package = "mFD")  # only keep traits 1 - 4: fruits_traits_cat <- fruits_traits_cat[1:4, ]  knitr::kable(head(fruits_traits_cat),               caption = "Traits types based on *fruits & baskets* dataset") # summarize species assemblages:  asb_sp_fruits_summ <- mFD::asb.sp.summary(baskets_fruits_weights) ## Error in get(paste0(generic, ".", class), envir = get_method_env()) :  ##   object 'type_sum.accel' not found # retrieve species occurrences for the first 3 assemblages (fruits baskets): head(asb_sp_fruits_summ$asb_sp_occ, 3) ##          apple apricot banana currant blackberry blueberry cherry grape ## basket_1     1       0      1       0          0         0      1     0 ## basket_2     1       0      1       0          0         0      1     0 ## basket_3     1       0      1       0          0         0      1     0 ##          grapefruit kiwifruit lemon lime litchi mango melon orange ## basket_1          0         0     1    0      0     0     1      0 ## basket_2          0         0     1    0      0     0     1      0 ## basket_3          0         0     1    0      0     0     1      0 ##          passion_fruit peach pear pineapple plum raspberry strawberry tangerine ## basket_1             1     0    1         0    0         0          1         0 ## basket_2             1     0    1         0    0         0          1         0 ## basket_3             1     0    1         0    0         0          1         0 ##          water_melon ## basket_1           0 ## basket_2           0 ## basket_3           0 asb_sp_fruits_occ <- asb_sp_fruits_summ$"asb_sp_occ"

title: How to Deal With Functional Entities

what: 4. Compute alpha and beta functional indices
title: How to Deal With Functional Entities
text: based data frame containing value traits FE, workflow one listed mFD General Workflow compute functional trait based distance, multidimensional functional space associated plots compute alpha beta functional indices (step 3 till end). thus summed tutorial.  mFD also allows compute functional indices based FEs following framework proposed Mouillot et al. 2014) using mFD::alpha.fd.fe() function. computes: Functional Redundancy reflects average number species per FE Functional Overredundancy reflects proportion species excess species-rich FE ie represents percentage species fill functional entities mean level functional redundancy Functional Vulnerability reflects proportion FE one species  mFD::alpha.fd.fe() function used follows:  USAGE  takes inputs: asb_sp_occ assemblages-species occurrence dataframe retrieved step 2 mFD::sp.tr.summary() function sp_to_fe list details species clustering FE mFD::sp..fe() ind_nm vector referring indices compute: fred Functional Redundancy, fored Functional Overredundancy fvuln Functional Vulnerability. check_input logical value reflecting whether inputs checked . Possible error messages thus understandable user R error messages NOTE Recommendation: set TRUE. details_returned logical value indicating whether user wants details_returned. Details used graphical functions thus must kept user want graphical outputs computed indices.  Let’s apply function fruits dataset:   function returns dataframe indices values assemblage detailed list containing matrix gathering number species per FE assemblage:
code: mFD::alpha.fd.fe(   asb_sp_occ       = asb_sp_fruits_occ,    sp_to_fe         = sp_to_fe_fruits,   ind_nm           = c("fred", "fored", "fvuln"),   check_input      = TRUE,   details_returned = TRUE) alpha_fd_fe_fruits <- mFD::alpha.fd.fe(   asb_sp_occ       = asb_sp_fruits_occ,    sp_to_fe         = sp_to_fe_fruits,   ind_nm           = c("fred", "fored", "fvuln"),   check_input      = TRUE,   details_returned = TRUE) # dataframe with indices values for each assemblage: alpha_fd_fe_fruits$"asb_fdfe" ## $asb_fe_nbsp ##           fe_3 fe_2 fe_7 fe_1 fe_8 fe_9 fe_4 fe_5 fe_10 fe_11 fe_6 fe_12 fe_13 ## basket_1     2    1    1    1    0    0    1    0     0     0    1     1     0 ## basket_2     2    1    1    1    0    0    1    0     0     0    1     1     0 ## what: 5. Plot functional indices based on FEs
title: How to Deal With Functional Entities
text: , possible graphical representation FE-based indices given assemblage using mFD::alpha.fe.fd.plot() function:  USAGE  function takes inputs: alpha_fe_fe_fruits output function mFD::alpha.fd.fe() applied assemblage interest details_returned = TRUE plot_asb_nm vector containing name assemblage plot plot_ind_nm vector containing names indices plot. fred plot functional redundancy (FRed), fored plot functional -redundancy (FOred) /fvuln plot functional vulnerability (FVuln) name_file character string name file save figure. set NULL plot displayed inputs personalize plot (details: see help file mFD::alpha.fd.fe.plot) check_input logical value reflecting whether inputs checked . Possible error messages thus understandable user R error messages NOTE Recommendation: set TRUE  studied example, plot looks follows:    FE except “fe_3” contain one species thus FRed FVuln close 1. “fe_3” species average number species thus proportion species excess FE richer average quite low (FORed = 0.107).
code: mFD::alpha.fd.fe.plot(   alpha_fd_fe       = alpha_fd_fe_fruits,   plot_asb_nm       = c("basket_1"),   plot_ind_nm       = c("fred", "fored", "fvuln"),   name_file         = NULL,   color_fill_fored  = "darkolivegreen2",   color_line_fred   = "darkolivegreen4",   color_fill_bar    = "grey80",   color_fill_fvuln  = "lightcoral",   color_arrow_fvuln = "indianred4",   size_line_fred    = 1.5,   size_arrow_fvuln  = 1,   check_input       = TRUE) mFD::alpha.fd.fe.plot(   alpha_fd_fe       = alpha_fd_fe_fruits,   plot_asb_nm       = c("basket_1"),   plot_ind_nm       = c("fred", "fored", "fvuln"),   name_file         = NULL,   color_fill_fored  = "darkolivegreen2",   color_line_fred   = "darkolivegreen4",   color_fill_bar    = "grey80",   color_fill_fvuln  = "lightcoral",   color_arrow_fvuln = "indianred4",   size_line_fred    = 1.5,   size_arrow_fvuln  = 1,   check_input       = TRUE) ## Warning in ggplot2::geom_segment(ggplot2::aes(x = fe_vuln_k[1], y = 0.5, : All aesthetics have length 1, but the data has 7 rows. ## ℹ Please consider using `annotate()` or provide this layer with data containing ##   a single row.

title: mFD: General Workflow
text: tutorial describes basic workflow showing compute step step functional diversity (FD) indices multidimensional space using mFD package. functions available uses illustrated others tutorials. DATA dataset used illustrate tutorial fruits dataset based 25 types fruits (.e. species) distributed 10 fruits baskets (.e. assemblages). fruit characterized five traits values summarized following table:

title: mFD: General Workflow
text: use mFD package based two datasets: data frame summarizing traits values species called fruits_traits tutorial Species x traits data frame  matrix summarizing species assemblages called baskets_fruits_weights tutorial. Weights matrix can occurrence data, abundance, biomass, coverage, etc. matrix must assemblages names rownames. studied example works biomass (.e. grams fruit basket) matrix looks follows: Species x assemblages matrix based fruits dataset  tutorial guide main framework, illustrated flowchart , step step.  Basic framework mFD package
code: # Load data: data("fruits_traits", package = "mFD")  # Remove fuzzy traits in this tutorial: fruits_traits <- fruits_traits[ , -c(6:8)]  # Display the table: knitr::kable(head(fruits_traits),              caption = "Species x traits data frame") # Load data: data("baskets_fruits_weights", package = "mFD")  # Display the table: knitr::kable(as.data.frame(baskets_fruits_weights[1:6, 1:6]),        centering = TRUE,       caption = "Species x assemblages matrix based on the **fruits** dataset")

what: 1.1. What types of traits am I using?
title: mFD: General Workflow
text: first thing starting analyses know data. , must able characterize traits using (.e. tell package type traits using). mFD package needs data frame summarizing type trait (.e. column fruits_traits data frame). NB need set data frame columns names example traits names need order fruits_traits data frame: Traits types based fruits & baskets dataset first column contains traits name. second column contains traits type following code: N: nominal trait (factor variable) O: ordinal traits (ordered variable) C: circular traits (integer values) (NB circular traits can used mFD function used compute functional distance ok summary function function group species Functional Entities) Q: quantitative traits (numeric values) F: fuzzy traits (described several values defined several columns fruits_traits data frame) can add third column dataset use fuzzy traits (third column summarizes fuzzy trait belongs column refers fuzzy trait) want give weight traits (third column summarizes traits weights).  NOTE traits types dataframe thus : two columns fuzzy traits weight given traits (columns names: trait_name trait_type) ; three columns fuzzy traits (columns names: trait_name,trait_type fuzzy_name) fuzzy traits weight given traits (columns names: trait_name,trait_type trait_weight). See first part Compute Functional Diversity Hill Indices see fruits_traits fruits_traits_cat look like fuzzy traits.
code: # Load data: data("fruits_traits_cat", package = "mFD")  # Remove fuzzy traits in this tutorial: fruits_traits_cat <- fruits_traits_cat[-c(6:8), ] # Thus remove the "fuzzy_name" column: fruits_traits_cat <- fruits_traits_cat[ , -3]  # Display the table: knitr::kable(head(fruits_traits_cat),               caption = "Traits types based on **fruits & baskets** dataset")

title: mFD: General Workflow
text: mFD package helps summarize data using two distinct functions: mFD::sp.tr.summary() mFD::asb.sp.summary(). function mFD::sp.tr.summary() summarizes fruits_traits dataframe returns list gathering several tables lists: tables summaries non-fuzzy & fuzzy traits. non-fuzzy traits, table sums number species category ordinal, nominal circular traits minimum/first quartile/median/mean/third quartile/maximum continuous traits. fuzzy traits, table sums minimum/first quartile/median/mean/third quartile/maximum category fuzzy trait. list gathering traits types non-fuzzy traits list gathering modalities non-continuous non-fuzzy traits  USAGE
code: # Species traits summary: fruits_traits_summ <- mFD::sp.tr.summary(   tr_cat     = fruits_traits_cat,      sp_tr      = fruits_traits,    stop_if_NA = TRUE) ## Error in get(paste0(generic, ".", class), envir = get_method_env()) :  ##   object 'type_sum.accel' not found fruits_traits_summ$"tr_types"                     # Traits types ## $Size ## [1] "ordered" "factor"  ##  ## $Plant ## [1] "factor" ##  ## $Climate ## [1] "ordered" "factor"  ##  ## $Seed ## [1] "ordered" "factor"  ##  ## $Sugar ## [1] "numeric" fruits_traits_summ$"mod_list"                     # Traits types for non-continuous and non-fuzzy traits ## $Size ## [1] 5-10cm  3-5cm   10-20cm 0-1cm   1-3cm   ## Levels: 0-1cm < 1-3cm < 3-5cm < 5-10cm < 10-20cm ##  ## $Plant ## [1] tree  shrub forb  vine  ## Levels: forb shrub tree vine ##  ## $Climate ## [1] temperate   tropical    subtropical ## Levels: temperate < subtropical < tropical ##  ## $Seed ## [1] pip  pit  none ## Levels: none < pip < pit ##  ## $Sugar ##  [1] 103.9  92.4 122.3  73.7  48.8 100.0 128.2 162.5  73.1  89.9  25.0  16.9 ## [13] 152.3 136.6  78.6  91.4 112.0  83.9  97.5  98.5  99.2  44.0  48.9 105.8 ## [25]  81.2

title: mFD: General Workflow
text: many species described categorical ordinal traits , might want group Functional Entities (FE), .e groups species trait values species described categorical /ordinal traits. particularly useful using large datasets “functionally similar” species. tutorial, function illustrated (FE fruits dataset single species) thus functional diversity indices based FE computed. can look Compute Functional Diversity Indices based Functional Entities tutorial analysis using FE.  mFD also allows user compute FD indices based Functional Entities (FEs). Computed indices Functional Redundancy (FRed), Functional OverRedundancy (FORed) Functional Vulnerability (FVuln) (Mouillot et al. 2014). fruits & baskets example allow compute FEs, thus FD indices based FEs can compute. Check Compute functional diversity indices based Functional Entities tutorial see compute .

what: 3. Computing distances between species based on functional traits
title: mFD: General Workflow
text: next step toward computation functional diversity indices estimate functional traits-based distances species order build functional space indices computed. compute trait-based distances, use mFD::funct.dist() function includes following arguments:  USAGE sp_tr species x trait data frame tr_cat data frame summarizing trait type trait metric character string referring metric used compute distances. Two metrics available choice depends traits data: traits continuous use Euclidean distance (metric = "euclidean") check Compute Functional Diversity Indices based Continuous Traits tutorial explains build multidimensional space traits PCA analysis considering directly trait dimension. non-continuous traits use Gower distance (metric = "gower") method allows traits weighting. method can also deal fuzzy traits. scale_euclid character string referring way user wants scale euclidean traits. can either chose scale range range, use center transformation center, use scale transformation scale, use scale-center transformation scale_center can chose scale noscale. ordinal_var character string specifying method used ordinal variables (.e. ordered). can either chose treat ordinal variables continuous variables ("classic" option) treat ordinal variables ranks (metric podani options, see mFD::funct.dist() help file details). weight_type character string referring type method weight traits. can either chose define weights using tr_cat dataframe (cf step 1.1) (user option) can chose give weight traits (equal option). (NB Using mFD, can define weights fuzzy traits, use gawdis package instead) (NB continuous traits (see Continuous traits Framework: using 1.0.6.9 version mFD package allow weighting, done next version package. can use col.w argument PCA function FactomineR package.) stop_if_NA logical value stop process sp_tr data frame contains NA. sp_tr data frame contains NA can either chose compute anyway functional distances (keep mind Functional measures sensitive missing traits!) can delete species missing extrapolate missing traits (see Johnson et al. (2020)).  NB data gather high number species /traits, function might take time run (might memory issues).  function returns dist object traits-based distances pairs species:

what: 4.1. Compute multimensional functional spaces and assess their quality
title: mFD: General Workflow
text: order generate multidimensional space functional diversity indices computed (Mouillot et al. 2013, perform PCoA using trait-based distances (required functional dendrogram). mFD evaluates quality PCoA-based multidimensional spaces according deviation trait-based distances distances functional space (extension Maire et al. (2015) framework). , use mFD::quality.fspaces() function:  USAGE sp_dist dist object pairwise trait-based distance species computed step 3 maxdim_pcoa maximum number PCoA axes consider build multidimensional spaces. Actually, maximum number dimensions considered depends number PCoA axes positive eigenvalues. deviation_weighting refers method(s) used weight difference species pairwise distances functional space trait-based distances. can chose : absolute: absolute differences used compute mean absolute deviation (mad) . reflects actual magnitude errors affect FD metrics. squared: squared differences used compute root mean square deviation (rmsd). weighting puts weight large deviations trait-based distances distances functional space. misplaced functional space. quality metrics can used deviation_weighting = c("absolute", "squared"). fdist_scaling specifies whether distances functional space scaled computing differences trait-based distances. Scaling ensures trait-based distances distances functional space maximum. Scaling distances implies quality functional space accounts congruence distances rather equality. NOTE combination deviation_weighting fdist_scaling arguments leads four possible quality metrics: mad, rmsd, mad_scaled rmsd_scaled fdendro specifies clustering algorithm compute functional dendrogram. NULL means dendrogram computed. chosen algorithm must one method recognized stats::hclust() function stats package.  function returns list various objects:  data frame gathering space (rows), values quality metric(s) (columns)  lists details required tasks step 4 plot functional space quality step 5 plot functional space.  NOTE space best quality lowest quality metric. , thanks mad values, can see 4D space best one. following tutorial use multidimensional space.

what: 4.2. Illustrating the quality of the selected functional spaces
title: mFD: General Workflow
text: mFD package, possible illustrate quality PCoA-based multidimensional spaces according deviation trait-based distances distances functional space. , use mFD::quality.fspace.plot() function following arguments:  Note: might encounter following error plot mFD: Error Ops.data.frame(guide_loc, panel_loc) : # ‘==’ defined equally-sized data frames} error due update patchwork package, able run plots, please update patchwork package vers. 1.2.0 least.  USAGE fspaces_quality output mFD::quality.fspaces() function (step 4.1). quality_metric refers quality metric used. one column name(s) table gathering quality metric values (output mFD::quality.fspaces() called quality_fspaces) (: fspaces_quality_fruits$quality_fspaces) Thus can : mad, rmsd, mad_scaled rmsd_scaled (see step 4.1) fspaces_plot refers names spaces quality illustrated (10). Names used output mFD::quality.fspaces() function showing values quality metric. name_file refers name file save (without extension) user wants save figure. user wants plot displayed, name_file = NULL. range_dist, range_dev, range_qdev arguments set ranges panel axes (check function help information). gradient_deviation gradient_deviation_quality arguments set points colors (check function help information). xlab parameter set x-axis label.  function generates figure three panels (rows) selected functional space (columns). column represents functional space, value quality metric written top column. x-axis panels represents trait-based distances. y-axis different row: first (top) row, y-axis represents species functional distances multidimensional space. Thus, closer species 1:1 line, better distances functional space fit trait-based ones. second row, y-axis shows raw deviation species distances functional space compared trait-based distances. Thus, raw deviation reflects distance 1:1 line. third row, y-axis shows absolute squared deviation (“scaled”) distance functional space. deviation taken account computing quality metric.    2D space, top row lot points 1:1 lines, meaning distances overestimated multidimensional space. Looking panels, can see 4D space one points closest 1:1 line top row,closest x-axis two bottom rows, reflects better quality compared functional spaces / dendrogram. dendrogram, can see top row species pairs arrange horizontal lines, meaning different trait-based distances cophenetic distance dendrogram.  NOTE know better understand interpret quality functional spaces, read Compute Interpret Quality Functional Space tutorial.

what: 5. Test correlation between functional axes and traits
title: mFD: General Workflow
text: mFD allows test correlations traits functional axes illustrate possible correlations. continuous traits, linear model computed r2 associated p-value returned. non-continuous traits, Kruskal-Wallis test computed eta2 statistic returned. function mFD::traits.faxes.cor() allows test plot correlation needs following arguments: sp_tr species x traits data frame sp_faxes_coord matrix species coordinates taken outputs mFD::quality.fspaces() function columns representing axes functional space must computed. instance, tutorial, plot functional space 4 10 dimensions (cf. two examples ). whole sp_faxes_coord can retrieved output mFD::quality.fspaces() function:  plot logical value indicating whether correlations illustrated . option set TRUE, traits-axis relationships plotted scatterplot continuous traits boxplot non-continuous traits. mFD::traits.faxes.cor works follows: USAGE can print traits significant effect position along one axis look plots:    can thus see PC1 mostly driven Climate (temperate left tropical right) Plant Type (forb & shrub left vs tree & vine right) Size (large fruits right) weaker influence Seed (eta2 < 0.25). , PC2 mostly driven Seed (seed left pit seed right) weaker influence Plant Type. PC3 driven one trait, Size. finally PC4 mostly driven Sugar (high sugar content right low sugar content left) weaker influence Plant Type.
code: sp_faxes_coord_fruits <- fspaces_quality_fruits$"details_fspaces"$"sp_pc_coord" fruits_tr_faxes <- mFD::traits.faxes.cor(   sp_tr          = fruits_traits,    sp_faxes_coord = sp_faxes_coord_fruits[ , c("PC1", "PC2", "PC3", "PC4")],    plot           = TRUE) # Print traits with significant effect: fruits_tr_faxes$"tr_faxes_stat"[which(fruits_tr_faxes$"tr_faxes_stat"$"p.value" < 0.05), ] ##      trait axis           test stat value p.value ## 1     Size  PC1 Kruskal-Wallis eta2 0.308  0.0377 ## 3     Size  PC3 Kruskal-Wallis eta2 0.326  0.0325 ## 5    Plant  PC1 Kruskal-Wallis eta2 0.471  0.0049 ## 6    Plant  PC2 Kruskal-Wallis eta2 0.382  0.0116 ## 8    Plant  PC4 Kruskal-Wallis eta2 0.264  0.0360 ## 9  Climate  PC1 Kruskal-Wallis eta2 0.731  0.0001 ## 13    Seed  PC1 Kruskal-Wallis eta2 0.201  0.0402 ## 14    Seed  PC2 Kruskal-Wallis eta2 0.593  0.0005 ## 20   Sugar  PC4   Linear Model   r2 0.682  0.0000 # Return plots: fruits_tr_faxes$"tr_faxes_plot"

what: 7.1. Functional alpha diversity indices in a multidimensional space
title: mFD: General Workflow
text: mFD::alpha.fd.multidim() function allows computing many alpha FD indices:  USAGE  arguments use listed : sp_faxes_coord species coordinates matrix. dataframe gathers axis functional space chosen based step 4. asb_sp_w matrix linking species assemblages belong (summarized step 1). ind_vect vector names diversity functional indices compute. FD indices computed mFD package can (explanations based (Mouillot et al. 2013): FDis Functional Dispersion: biomass weighted deviation species traits values center functional space filled assemblage .e. biomass-weighted mean distance biomass-weighted mean trait values assemblage. FRic Functional Richness: proportion functional space filled species studied assemblage, .e. volume inside convex-hull shaping species. compute FRic number species must least higher number functional axis + 1. FDiv Functional Divergence: proportion biomass supported species extreme functional traits .e. ones located close edge convex-hull filled assemblage. FEve Functional Evenness: regularity biomass distribution functional space using Minimum Spanning Tree linking species present assemblage. FSpe Functional Specialization: biomass weighted mean distance mean position species global pool (present assemblages). FMPD Functional Mean Pairwise Distance: mean weighted distance species pairs. FNND Functional Mean Nearest Neighbour Distance: weighted distance nearest neighbor within assemblage. FIde Functional Identity: mean traits values assemblage. FIde always computed FDis computed. FOri Functional Originality: weighted mean distance nearest species global species pool. scaling logical value indicating whether indices scaled 0 1. scaling done, argument must set TRUE. check_input recurrent argument mFD package. defines whether inputs checked computation . Possible error messages thus understandable user R error messages (Recommendation: set TRUE). details_returned used user wants store information used graphical functions. user wants plot FD indices, details_returned must set TRUE.  NB Use lowercase letters enter FD indices names  function two main outputs: data frame gathering indices values assemblage (FIde values, many columns axes studied functional space).  details list data frames sublists gathering information coordinates centroids, distances identity nearest neighbour, distances centroid, etc. user directly use useful FD indices plotted. can retrieved :  , can plot functional indices using mFD::alpha.multidim.plot() function follows:  USAGE  can see, function lot arguments: graphical arguments allowing user chose colors, shapes, sizes, scales, etc. tutorial presents main arguments. learn use graphical arguments, check function help file. main arguments function listed : output_alpha_fd_multidim output `mFD::alpha.fd.multidim() function. plot_asb_nm vector gathering name(s) assemblage(s) plot. ind_vect vector gathering FD indices plot. Plots available FDis, FIde, FEve, FRic, FDiv, FOri, FSpe, FNND. faxes vector containing names axes plot. can plot two four axes labels graphical reasons. faxes_nm vector axes labels user ants different axes labels faxes ones. range_faxes vector minimum maximum values axes. range_faxes = c(NA, NA), range computed according range values among axes, axes thus range. fair representation species positions plots, axes must range. plot_sp_nm vector containing species names plot. NULL, name plotted. size, color, fill, shape arguments component graphs .e. species global pool, species studied assemblage(s), vertices, centroids segments. plot two assemblages, inputs formatted follow: c(pool = ..., asb1 = ..., asb2 = ...) inputs used global pool studied assemblages c(asb1 = ..., asb2 = ...) inputs used studied assemblages . check_input recurrent argument mFD. defines whether inputs checked computation . Possible error messages thus understandable user R error messages (Recommendation: set TRUE.  , using arguments, output plots fruits & baskets dataset:  FRic representation: colored shapes reflect convex-hull studied assemblages white shape reflects convex-hull global pool species:   FDiv representation: gravity centers vertices (.e. species extreme functional traits) assemblages plotted square triangle. Species assemblage different size given relative weight assemblage.   FSpe representation: colored traits represent distances species given assemblage center gravity global pool (.e center functional space). center gravity plotted purple diamond. Species assemblage different size given relative weight assemblage.   FDis representation: colored traits represent distances species given assemblage center gravity species assemblage (defined FIde values). center gravity assemblage plotted using square triangle. Species assemblage havedifferent size given relative weight assemblage.   FIde representation:colored lines refer weighted average position species assemblage along axis. Species assemblage different size given relative weight assemblage.   FEve representation: colored traits represent Minimum Spanning Tree linking species assemblage. Species assemblage different size given relative weight assemblage.   FOri representation: colored arrows represent distances species assemblage nearest species global species pool. Species assemblage different size given relative weight assemblage.  FNND representation: colored arrows represent distances species assemblage nearest species studied assemblage. Species assemblage different size given relative weight assemblage.

what: 7.2. Functional beta diversity indices based on multidimensional space
title: mFD: General Workflow
text: NOTE: Mac OS X 10.15 may encounter issues beta_*() functions.  mFD package allows compute beta diversity indices assemblage pairs following Villeger et al. 2013. use mFD::beta.fd.multidim() function.  NOTE function can compute two families functional beta diversity indices, either Jaccard Sorensen.  example, use Jaccard index. assemblages pair, dissimilarity index decomposed two additive components: turnover nestedness-resultant. NB turnover component highest shared traits combination two assemblages. nestedness component highest one assemblage hosts small subset functional strategies present .  mFD::beta.fd.multidim() function main following arguments:  USAGE  sp_faxes_coord species coordinates matrix. dataframe gathers axis functional space chosen based step 4. asb_sp_occ matrix occurrence (coded 0/1) species assemblages (summarized step 1). check_input recurrent argument mFD package. defines whether inputs checked computation . Possible error messages thus understandable user R error messages (Recommendation: set TRUE. beta_family character string type beta-diversity index compute, can either Jaccard Sorensen. details_returned logical value indicating whether details outputs must stored. stored plan use graphical function illustrate beta diversity indices thereafter. also arguments parallelisation options. Check function help file explanation.  function returns list containing: dist object beta indices values pair assemblages  list containing details inputs, vertices global pool assemblage FRic values assemblage  vector containing FRic value assemblage retrieved details_beta list list vectors containing names species vertices convex hull assemblage retrieved details_beta list , package allows user illustrate functional beta-diversity indices pair assemblages multidimensional space using mFD::beta.multidim.plot() function. output function figure showing overlap convex hulls shaping two species assemblages.  plotting function large number arguments, allowing user chose graphical options. Arguments listed :  USAGE  output_beta_fd_multidim output mFD::beta.fd.multidim() function retrieved beta_fd_indices. plot_asb_nm vector containing name two assemblages plot. plots indices shown basket_1 basket_4. beta_family refers family plotted index. must family chosen compute beta functional indices values mFD::beta.fd.multidim() function. plot_sp_nm vector containing names species user want plot, . user want plot species name, argument must set NULL. , apple, cherry lemon plotted graph. faxes vector containing names functional axes plotted functional space. , figure plotted PC1, PC2 PC3. function allows plot two four axes graphical reasons. name_file character string name file save figure (without extension). user want save file display , argument must set NULL. faxes_nm vector containing axes labels figure user wants set different labels contained faxes. range_faxes vector minimum maximum values functional axes. fair representation position species plots, axes range. user wants range computed according range values among axes, argument must set c(NA, NA). check_input recurrent argument mFD package. defines whether inputs checked computation . Possible error messages thus understandable user R error messages (Recommendation: set TRUE) Others arguments set colors, shapes, sizes , text fonts also available. information , read function help file.  , function returns graph functional axes combination also multipanel plot combinations axes graph caption. assemblage, associated convex hull plotted different colour indices values printed right corner plot. Vertices convex hull given assemblage can plotted different symbol example. Species assemblages plotted gray cross associated convex hull plotted white.

title: Compute and Illustrate the Multiple Facets of Functional Diversity
text: compute functional diversity indices, users need: data frame summarizing species traits (species rows, traits columns). mFD package works kind traits: quantitative, ordinal, nominal, circular, fuzzy-coded. matrix summarizing species gathering assemblages (assemblages rows, species columns). assemblages must least contain one species. data frame summarizing traits category (first column traits name, second column traits type, third column fuzzy name fuzzy traits - fuzzy traits: NA). complete understanding functional workflow package possibilities, please refer mFD General Workflow.
code: library("mFD")

title: Compute and Illustrate the Multiple Facets of Functional Diversity

(2022). mFD: R package compute illustrate multiple facets functional diversity. Ecography https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ecog.05904 can also run:

what: Compute the set of indices based on number of species in Functional Entities — alpha.fd.fe
title: Compute the set of indices based on number of species in Functional Entities — alpha.fd.fe
text: function computes set indices based number species Functional Entities (FEs) following Mouillot et al. (2014).

title: Compute the set of indices based on number of species in Functional Entities — alpha.fd.fe
code: alpha.fd.fe(   asb_sp_occ,   sp_to_fe,   ind_nm = c("fred", "fored", "fvuln"),   check_input = TRUE,   details_returned = TRUE )

title: Compute the set of indices based on number of species in Functional Entities — alpha.fd.fe
text: asb_sp_occ matrix linking occurrences (coded 0/1) species (columns) set assemblages (rows). Warning: assemblage must contain least one species. sp_to_fe list details species clustering FE sp..fe. ind_nm vector character strings names functional diversity indices compute among 'fred', 'fored' 'fvuln'. Indices names must written lower case letters. Default: indices computed. check_input logical value indicating whether key features inputs checked (e.g. class /mode objects, names rows /columns, missing values). error detected, detailed message returned. Default: check.input = TRUE. details_returned logical value indicating whether details indices computation returned. details required alpha.fd.fe.plot plot FEs indices.

title: Compute the set of indices based on number of species in Functional Entities — alpha.fd.fe
text: list : asb_fdfe matrix containing assemblage (rows), values functional diversity indices (names 'ind_nm') well number species ('nb_sp') number FE (nb_fe); details_returned TRUE, details_fdfe list asb_fe_nbsp matrix number species per FE assemblage.

title: Compute the set of indices based on number of species in Functional Entities — alpha.fd.fe
text: Mouillot et al. (2014) Functional -redundancy high functional vulnerability global fish faunas tropical reefs. PNAS, 38, 13757-13762.

title: Compute the set of indices based on number of species in Functional Entities — alpha.fd.fe
text: Camille Magneville

title: Compute the set of indices based on number of species in Functional Entities — alpha.fd.fe
code: # Load Species*Traits dataframe: data('fruits_traits', package = 'mFD')  # Load Traits categories dataframe: data('fruits_traits_cat', package = 'mFD')  # Load Assemblages*Species matrix: data('baskets_fruits_weights', package = 'mFD')  # Remove continuous trait: fruits_traits <- fruits_traits[, -5] fruits_traits_cat <- fruits_traits_cat[-5, ]  # Compute gathering species into FEs: sp_to_fe_fruits <- mFD::sp.to.fe(sp_tr = fruits_traits,   tr_cat = fruits_traits_cat,   fe_nm_type = 'fe_rank', check_input = TRUE) #> Warning: All Functional Entities have a single species.   # Get the occurrence dataframe: asb_sp_fruits_summ <- mFD::asb.sp.summary(asb_sp_w = baskets_fruits_weights)  asb_sp_fruits_occ <- asb_sp_fruits_summ$'asb_sp_occ'  # Compute alpha fd indices: alpha.fd.fe(    asb_sp_occ       = asb_sp_fruits_occ,     sp_to_fe         = sp_to_fe_fruits,    ind_nm           = c('fred', 'fored', 'fvuln'),    check_input      = TRUE,     details_returned = TRUE) #> $asb_fdfe #>           nb_sp nb_fe fred fored fvuln #> basket_1      8     8    1     0     1 #> basket_2      8     8    1     0     1 #> basket_3      8     8    1     0     1 #> basket_4      8     8    1
